Prompt:
Example 1:
Daniel was but eight years old, a boy of striking appearance, with black hair and eyes, and a swarthy complexion. He was of slender frame, and his large dark eyes, deep set beneath an overhanging brow, gave a singular appearance to the thin face of the delicate looking boy. He was a farmer's son, and lived in a plain, old-fashioned house, shaded by fine elms, and separated from the broad, quiet street by a fence. It was situated in a valley, at the bend of the Merrimac, on both sides of which rose high hills, which the boy climbed many a time for the more extended view they commanded. From a high sheep-pasture on his father's farm, through a wide opening in the hills, he could see on a clear day Brentney Mountain in Vermont, and in a different direction the snowy top of Mount Washington, far away to the northeast.

Example 2:
There is no specific scientific calculator prescribed for this subject. Any scientific, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators have different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic; the operation in an expression can be entered in the calculator in the order in which the expression is read (left to right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which operations to perform first.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain order, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

Human aging is a natural process of physical and mental development that varies among individuals. As people grow, their bodies change, and their features become more pronounced. Skin, muscles, and organs undergo transformations that impact overall health and well-being. Aging affects every aspect of a person's life, from physical abilities to mental clarity.  The rate of aging can be influenced by genetics, lifestyle, and environmental factors.  In a normal, healthy life, aging is a gradual process that happens over time. It is characterized by wrinkles, grey hair, and loss of energy. As people age, they also gain life experience and wisdom.  Their brain develops new connections, and their senses become more acute.  The aging process is a complex and multifaceted phenomenon that affects everyone. It is a normal part of life that brings about both physical and mental changes. Human aging is a biological process marked by distinct physical, cognitive, and emotional changes. From adolescence to adulthood, noticeable changes occur in skin, hair, and body composition. These transformations have profound effects on our physical appearance, energy levels, and mental capabilities. Aging is an inevitable part of life.  ​

Answer: 

Human aging is a biological process characterized by distinct physical, cognitive, and emotional changes. From adolescence to adulthood, noticeable changes occur in skin, hair, and body composition. These transformations have profound effects on our physical appearance, energy levels, and mental capabilities, marking a life-altering experience.  ​

As we age, our bodies undergo many changes. Our skin loses elasticity, wrinkles appear, and our eyes lose their brightness. We become thinner and less agile, and our hearing and vision decline. These changes are a natural part of life, and we must learn to adapt to them. They signal our growth and development. 
Our bodies grow stronger, and our minds become wiser. We gain life experience, and our thoughts become more refined. Our appearance changes, but our inner strength and character remain the same. We continue to grow and learn, even in our later years. Our life is a continuous journey of growth and transformation.  [ deleted  ].

Most scientific calculators have algebraic logic; the operation in an expression can be entered in the calculator in the order in which the expression is read (left to right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator to work either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes fractions, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed as you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we come across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how we choose which operations to perform first.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to follow preset mathematical rules. If we press the buttons in a certain order, the calculator does the operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (High School), limited to 50 words.
Text:
Example 1:
Daniel was but eight years old, a boy of striking appearance, with black hair and eyes, and a swarthy complexion. He was of slender frame, and his large dark eyes, deep set beneath an overhanging brow, gave a singular appearance to the thin face of the delicate looking boy. He was a farmer's son, and lived in a plain, old-fashioned house, shaded by fine elms, and separated from the broad, quiet street by a fence. It was situated in a valley, at the bend of the Merrimac, on both sides of which rose high hills, which the boy climbed many a time for the more extended view they commanded. From a high sheep-pasture on his father's farm, through a wide opening in the hills, he could see on a clear day Brentney Mountain in Vermont, and in a different direction the snowy top of Mount Washington, far away to the northeast.

Human aging is a complex phenomenon. Physically, we notice signs of aging as wrinkles, grey hair, and declining mobility. Emotionally, we experience changes in personality, values, and life goals. As we age, our brain undergoes structural changes, affecting memory and cognitive function. Our overall health also declines with time. 
The aging process varies from person to person, and its pace is influenced by genetics, lifestyle, and environmental factors. Understanding human aging can help us prepare for the future and make informed decisions about our health and well-being.

As a human ages, a series of physical and biological changes occur. Muscles lose mass, skin wrinkles, and hair turns gray. The heart rate and breathing rate decrease.
